Hydrodeoxygenation of 1,2-decanediol to produce 1-decanol over Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst Yue Li a Huan Ren a Daolai Sun a b ⁎ Xinqiang Zhao a ⁎⁎ Satoshi Sato b ⁎⁎ a Tianjin Key Laboratory of Chemical Process Safety, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China Tianjin Key Laboratory of Chemical Process Safety, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300130 China School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin, 300130, China b Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Chiba 263-8522, Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University Chiba 263-8522 Japan Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba University, Chiba, 263–8522, Japan ⁎ Corresponding author at: School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology, Tianjin 300130, China. School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300130 China. ⁎⁎ Corresponding authors. Liquid-phase catalytic hydrodeoxygenation of 1,2-decanediol (1,2-DDO) to form 1-decanol was performed over various non-noble metal-loaded acidic catalysts, and Cu loaded on amorphous SiO2-Al2O3 exhibited a high catalytic activity for the formation of 1-decanol. A high 1-decanol selectivity of 84.7% with a complete 1,2-DDO conversion was obtained within only 15 min over the Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 at 250 °C under 10 MPa H2 pressure. The temperature at 250 °C and the H2 pressure higher than 3 MPa were conducive to the efficient production of 1-decanol from 1,2-DDO. In contrast to the previously reported noble metal catalysts, Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 required a relatively high reaction temperature, while an extremely high 1-decanol productivity of 78 mmol gcat −1 h−1 could be achieved. Meanwhile, the hydrodeoxygenation of 1,2-decanediol over Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 proceeded via a reaction mechanism in which decanal was formed as the intermediate. In addition, the Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst was reusable at least five times without serious deactivation. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords 1,2-decanediol Hydrodeoxygenation Efficient conversion 1-decanol Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction In recent decades, the sustainable development in chemical industry is highly concerned, and biomass as a renewable resource has been pushed onto the historical stage [1]. The inexhaustible biomass is a promising alternative energy resource, and the catalytic conversion of biomass to form useful chemicals has drawn extensive attention [2,3]. Lignocellulose and sugar alcohols are important biomass raw materials readily achievable from nature, and they can be converted into various 1,2-vicinal diols, such as 1,2-butanediol [4], 1,2-pentanediol [5], and 1,2-hexanediol [6]. Polyols including 1,2-vicinal diols have high oxygen contents, which limits their widespread uses as either a fuel or a chemical in industry [7–11]. Consequently, the catalytic reduction of the oxygen content in polyols to produce valuable chemicals is required [12–14]. Generally, polyols are mainly deoxygenated via hydrolysis [15], hydrogenolysis [16–18], hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) [7,19], and deoxydehydration [20,21]. The main deoxygenated products are lower polyols, mono alcohols, olefins, and alkanes. Meanwhile, the selective removal of oxygen in polyols without breaking the C-C bond is a challenge [22]. The HDO of 1,2-diols leads to the formation of primary alcohols, such as 1-propanol, 1-butanol, and 1-hexanol, which have important uses as solvents and chemical intermediates in chemical industry [23–27]. Therefore, the HDO of 1,2-diols to form primary alcohols has attracted increasing research interests. A series of noble metal catalysts, such as Rh [28–31], Pt [17,32], Ru [33–35], Ir [9,36,37] and Pd [35,38] have been applied for the HDO of 1,2-vicinal diols. Tomishige et al. have widely studied the HDO of 1,2-diols such as 1,2-propanediol and 1,2-hexanediol over Rh- and Ir-based catalysts [9,28,29,35,36] and have found Re-modified Rh/SiO2 with a 1-propanol selectivity of 74.0% at a 1,2-propanediol conversion of 86.6% [28]. Chia et al. have conducted the HDO of various polyols, such as 1,2-butanediol, 1,2-pentanediol, and 1,2-hexanediol, over an active carbon-supported Rh-ReOx catalyst [30]. The selectivities to the corresponding 1-alcohols such as 1-propanol, 1-butanol, and 1-hexanol are 78.4%, 87.8%, and 79.5%, respectively, while the corresponding secondary alcohols such as 2-propanol, 2-butanol, and 2-hexanol are competitively formed as the main by-products, which decreases the selectivity to 1-alcohols. In the pioneering reports on HDO of 1,2-propanediol [28,32,36], the primary purpose of these works was the production of 1,3-propanediol from glycerol. Chen et al. have developed an excellent Pt/WO3/ZrO2 catalyst, which shows a high 1-propanol selectivity of 91.4% at a 1,2-propanediol conversion of 89.7% in a fixed-bed flow reactor at 140 °C and an H2 pressure of 4.0 MPa [32]. Although noble metal-based catalysts are effective for the HDO of 1,2-diols to form 1-alcohols, the high price of noble metals would limit the further application of these processes. In addition, a long reaction time as a day scale is required in a pressured batch reactor for achieving a high conversion level, suggesting that the productivity is not so high. In this study, the HDO of 1,2-decanediol (1,2-DDO) to form 1-decanol was selected as a model reaction, which was performed over a series of non-noble metal-based catalysts. The relationship between the catalyst property and the catalytic activity was studied. In addition, the effects of the reaction conditions, such as reaction temperature, H2 pressure, and reaction time, were investigated and the reaction mechanism was also discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Samples 1,2-DDO and 1,4-dioxane were purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry, Japan and Eon Chemical Technology Co., Ltd, China, respectively. An amorphous SiO2-Al2O3 (grade 135, Si/Al ratio of 14.4) and a γ-Al2O3 were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, USA and Strem Chemicals, USA, respectively. H-Mordenite, H-USY, SAPO-34, and H-Beta zeolites were supplied by Tianjin Nanhua Catalyst Co., Ltd, China. SiO2 (CARiACT Q10) with a mean pore diameter of 10 nm, a specific surface area of 294 m2 g−1, and a pore volume of 1.00 cm3 g−1 was supplied by Fuji Silycia Chemical Ltd, Japan. Cu(NO3)2·0.3 H2O and Co(NO3)2·0.6 H2O were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology, China. Ni(NO3)2·0.6 H2O was purchased from Shisaner Branch Plant, China. The reagents were used without further purification. The metal-loaded catalysts were prepared by an incipient wetness impregnation method. The preparation process is elaborated by taking the preparation of 12 wt% Cu-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 as an example. Cu(NO3)2·0.3 H2O of 2.132 g was accurately weighed and completely dissolved in 20 ml of distilled water with the assistance of an ultrasonic vibrator. A dozen drops of the solution was added to 4 g of SiO2-Al2O3, which was placed in an evaporating dish with the illumination of a 375 W tungsten lamp to evaporate the water. The operation was repeated until all of the Cu(NO3)2·0.3 H2O aqueous solution was added to the support. After the impregnation, the sample was dried in a muffle furnace overnight at 110 °C and then calcined at 300 °C for 3 h. The prepared catalysts were kept in a dry environment for a future use. Hereafter, the prepared catalysts are expressed as xA/B, where A, B, and x represent the species of the loaded metal, the species of the support material, and the weight percentage of the loaded metal A, respectively. For example, 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 represents the SiO2-Al2O3-supported Cu catalyst with a Cu metal loading of 12 wt%. 2.2 Catalytic reaction The reaction was performed in a 50 ml stainless batch type reactor. 1,2-DDO was dissolved in 1,4-dioxane with a mass ratio of 1:8. Then, 18 g of the prepared solution together with 0.5 g catalyst, which had been pre-reduced at 300 °C for 1 h in an H2 atmosphere at a pressure of 5 MPa, was added into the reactor. After the reactor was sealed, the reaction environment was purified by filling H2 with a pressure of 1.5 MPa for 3 times. The mechanical stirring speed was adjusted to 500 rpm, and the H2 pressure was set to 3 MPa before starting the reaction. The temperature was gradually raised from the room temperature to 250 °C within ca. 50 min, corresponding with that the H2 pressure gradually increased from 3 to ca. 5 MPa. The time count was started after the temperature reached 250 °C. After the prescribed time had passed, the reactor was cooled to the room temperature, and the reaction mixture was recovered. The solid catalyst was separated from the reaction solution through centrifugation and filtration, and it was recovered and stored after drying at 110 °C for 12 h. For the recycle runs, the used catalyst was calcined at 300 °C for 3 h and reduced at 300 °C for 1 h before the next run. The collected liquid products were analyzed by an FID-GC (GC-2010Pro, Shimadzu) with a 30-m capillary column of WondaCap WAX (GL-Science, Japan). A GC-MS (GCMS-QP2010SE, Shimadzu) was used for the identification of the products. 1-Butanol was selected as the internal standard substance. The conversion and the selectivity to each product were calculated as follows: 1,2 ‐ D D O c o n v e r s i o n % = 1 − moles of 1 , 2 ‐ DDO in the reaction solution moles of 1 , 2 ‐ DDO before the reaction × 100 P r o d u c t s e l e c t i v i t y % = moles of carbon in specific product moles of carbon in converted 1 , 2 ‐ DDO × 100 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The specific surface area (SBET), pore volume, and pore size of the catalyst samples were determined by N2 adsorption at − 196 °C using an 3H-2000PS2 (Beishide, China). The SBET was calculated from the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm by Brunauer-Eemmet-Teller (BET) method. The pore volume as well as pore size of SiO2-Al2O3 and γ-Al2O3 was calculated by Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, and those of H-Mordenite, H-USY, SAPO-34, and H-Beta zeolites were calculated by Non-Local Density Functional Theory (NLDFT) method. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were recorded on a D8 Discover (Bruker, Germany) using Cu Kα radiation. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) of a catalyst precursor was performed in order to understand the reduction behavior of the catalyst precursor. The TPR analysis was performed using a PCA-1200 (Builder, China) under the following conditions: flow rate of a mixed N2/H2 (9/1) gas, 30 cm3 min−1; heating rate, 5 °C min−1; heating range, from 25 to 900 °C. The temperature-programmed desorption of adsorbed NH3 (NH3-TPD) was performed using a PCA-1200 with a thermal conductivity detector to evaluate the acidic properties of the catalyst samples. Before the adsorption of NH3, the sample of ca. 0.11 g was preheated in an N2 flow at 500 °C for 1 h. The adsorption of NH3 was performed at 100 °C for 1 h, and then the sample was switched to a vacuum atmosphere with the temperature kept at 100 °C for 1 h. The desorption of NH3 was performed from 50 to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in an N2 flow of 30 cm3 min−1. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of the samples were observed on a Talos F200S (Thermal Fisher Scientific, USA). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted on an ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) with Al Kα as the excitation source. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Hydrodeoxygenation of 1,2-DDO over various metal-loaded solid acid catalysts A series of non-noble metal-loaded solid acid catalysts were prepared and evaluated in the HDO of 1,2-DDO. Some solid acids such as amorphous SiO2-Al2O3, γ-Al2O3, SAPO-34, H-USY, H-Beta, and H-Mordenite zeolites were used as the support. Non-noble metals such as Cu, Ni, and Co were used as the loaded metal with a metal loading of 12 wt%. Table 1 summarizes the textural properties of the supports as well as the metal-loaded catalysts. The SBET of γ-Al2O3 and SiO2-Al2O3 were 208 and 517 m2 g−1, respectively. The zeolites showed relatively high SBET values those were at a range of 619–862 m2 g−1. The loading of metal decreased the SBET and the pore volume. For example, the SBET and the pore volume of SiO2-Al2O3 support were 517 m2 g−1 and 0.73 cm3 g−1, and those were decreased to 383 m2 g−1 and 0.54 cm3 g−1 after 12 wt% Cu metal loading, respectively. The average pore sizes of 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 and 12Cu/γ-Al2O3 were 5.6 and 8.5 nm, respectively, suggesting that they primarily contained mesopores. In addition, the loading of metal on either SiO2-Al2O3 or γ-Al2O3 slightly decreased the average pore sizes, indicating that the loaded metal was located in the mesopores. Fig. 1 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and the pore size distribution of SiO2-Al2O3 and 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 samples. Both SiO2-Al2O3 and 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 showed an adsorption-desorption isotherm of Type IV according to the IUPAC classification [39], demonstrating the mesoporous structure of both SiO2-Al2O3 and 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3. Meanwhile, SiO2-Al2O3 and 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 showed pore size distributions at a peak top of 6 and 4 nm and with a range of 2–22 and 2–18 nm, respectively. On the other hand, the zeolites showed small average pore sizes of ca. 2 nm, suggesting that the zeolites contained both micropores and mesopores. Figs. S1-S5 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of γ-Al2O3, the zeolites and the Cu-loaded zeolites. γ-Al2O3 primarily contained mesopores. All the zeolites contained micropores, while H-Beta and H-USY also contained mesopores. Since the loading of Cu on the zeolites slightly increased the average pore sizes, the loaded Cu should be mainly located in the micropores. Fig. 2 shows the NH3-TPD profiles of Cu-loaded catalysts before reduction. All the desorption profiles of the samples composed of 2 or 3 desorption peaks at the temperature range of 100–800 °C, indicating the samples contained acid sites with different acid strengths. Both 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 and 12Cu/γ-Al2O3 showed two desorption peaks those appeared at the desorption temperatures lower than 450 °C. In contrast, all of the Cu-loaded zeolites showed 3 desorption peaks, in which the far right one was located at the desorption temperature higher than 450 °C, indicating that they contained more acidic sites with strong acidity. According to the desorption temperature, the acid sites were defined as weak, medium, and strong acid sites, corresponding to the desorption temperature range of 100–300, 300–450, and 450–800 °C, respectively. Table 2 summarizes the total acid amounts of the Cu-loaded catalysts as well as the divided acid amounts of the weak, medium, and strong acid sites. The Cu-loaded zeolites showed relatively high total acid amounts, meanwhile, they contained more strong acid sites than 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 and 12Cu/γ-Al2O3. On the other hand, 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 primarily contained weak and medium acid sites, and the acid amounts attributed to weak, medium, and strong acid sites were 442, 348, and 285 μmol g−1, respectively. Besides, it should be questionable that the strong acid sites desorbed at higher than 500 °C in the NH3-TPD work as active sites for the dehydration of 1,2-diols because they would be neutralized by water in the working state, as explained later. It is important to find out which sites are effective for the dehydration, which should be a further important work. The catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts was tested at 250 °C under an H2 pressure of 5 MPa for a reaction time of 4 h. Table 3 shows the results of the catalytic activity tests in the HDO of 1,2-DDO over various metal-loaded acid catalysts. The major detected products were 1-decanol, decanal, 2-decanone, 2-decanol, 1-decene, 2-decene and decane. The dehydration of 1,2-DDO could give two products, decanal and 2-decanone, which could be hydrogenated to form 1-decanol and 2-decanol, respectively. Further dehydration of 1-decanol and 2-decanol could form 1-decene and/or 2-decene. The isomerization between 1-decene and 2-decene possibly proceeded, and decane could be formed through the hydrogenation of the decenes, i.e. 1- and 2-decene. Others shown in Table 3 include unidentified products. In the reaction of 1,2-octanediol over WOx/TiO2 catalyst, a cyclic acetal, 2-heptyl-4-hexyl-1,3-dioxolane was produced at 180 °C [35]. In the vapor-phase dehydration of 1,2-propanediol to propanal at 300 °C [40], 2-ethyl-4-methyl-1,3-dioxolane was also formed over SiO2-Al2O3 at low conversions. Therefore, the unidentified products in the present study may contain a cyclic acetal, 2-nonyl-4-octyl-1,3-dioxolane. On the other hand, the formation of dialkyl ether was reported in some HDO processes of 1,2-diols [33,35,37]. In the present study, however, decyl ether was observed with a selectivity of 0.2% only in the reaction over 12Cu/H-Beta catalyst, whereas it was not detected in the reactions catalyzed by other catalysts. Among the tested catalysts, 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3, which had a mesopore structure with a moderate SBET and a relatively weak acidity, exhibited the best catalytic performance among the catalysts listed in Table 3, and a 1-decanol selectivity of 79.4% with a complete conversion of 1,2-DDO was achieved. Meanwhile, decenes and decane with the selectivity of 3.0% and 4.1%, respectively, were the main by-products in the identified products. The conversion of 1,2-DDO and the selectivity to 1-decanol were 99.8% and 57.3% over 12Cu/γ-Al2O3, respectively. Besides, 12Cu/γ-Al2O3 gave relatively high selectivities to 2-decanone and 2-decanol, those were 3.7% and 6.0%, respectively. 12Cu/H-USY primarily produced decanal with a selectivity of 49.4%, and the selectivity to 1-decanol was only 7.1%. In the case of 12Cu/H-Beta, 12Cu/H-Mordenite, and 12Cu/SAPO-34, 1-decanol was not preferentially produced, and a variety of unidentified products were formed. It is suggested that these Cu-loaded zeolites are less active in the hydrogenation of decanal. The activity of Co- and Ni-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts was also examined (Table 3). Both 12Ni/SiO2-Al2O3 and 12Co/SiO2-Al2O3 were pre-reduced in an H2 atmosphere at 400 °C for 1 h before the reaction. 12Co/SiO2-Al2O3 provided a complete conversion of 1,2-DDO with a 1-decanol selectivity of 49.8%, while decane was produced with a selectivity of 21.3%. 12Ni/SiO2-Al2O3 gave a complete 1,2-DDO conversion with a low 1-decanol selectivity of 1.1%, while some short chain alkanes such as nonane and octane in addition to decane were generated in large quantities. In particular, nonane and octane were produced with the selectivity of 56.3% and 7.3%, respectively, indicating that Ni showed a high activity for the cleavage of C-C bond [41,42], which led to the decomposition of 1,2-DDO and the formation of the short chain alkanes. Besides, no nonane was observed in the reaction catalyzed by Cu- and Co-based catalysts. 3.2 HDO of 1,2-DDO over Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts with different Cu loadings Since 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 exhibited a good catalytic performance for the formation of 1-decanol, Cu-loaded SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts with different Cu loadings were further prepared and characterized. Fig. 3 depicts the XRD patterns of Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts with different Cu loadings. The samples were reduced at 300 °C for 1 h before the analysis. Typical diffraction peaks of Cu at 2θ = 43.3, 50.4 and 74.1° were observed in the XRD profiles, which were attributed to the (111), (200), and (220) face of Cu (JCPDF 04–0836), respectively. The intensity of the diffraction peaks of Cu increased with increasing the Cu loading, indicating that large Cu particles with a high crystallinity were formed at high Cu loadings. In addition, no diffraction peak attributed to CuO or Cu2O was detected in the XRD patterns of all of the reduced catalysts [43]. XPS analysis of 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 was performed to identify the valence states of the Cu on the catalyst surface, and the sample was reduced at 300 °C for 1 h before the analysis. Fig. 4 depicts the XPS spectra of Cu 2p. The main peaks of Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 were detected at 932.6 and 952.5 eV, respectively [44,45]. The peak located 932.6 eV indicated that the catalyst sample contained Cu0 and/or Cu+, while it is difficult to identify the two valence states because their binding energies are very close, locating at 932.6 and 932.7 eV, respectively [46]. On the other hand, because no shakeup satellite peak of Cu2+ located at ca. 940 eV was observed, CuO component should not exist on the catalyst surface. Fig. 5 shows the TPR profiles of Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 with different Cu loadings. 4Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 and 8Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 showed a broad reduction peak at 263 and 260 °C, respectively. In 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 and 16Cu/SiO2-Al2O3, the peak top shifted to 251 and 249 °C, respectively. 20Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 showed two reduction peaks at 246 and 275 °C, indicating that large Cu particles were formed at a Cu loading of 20 wt%, and the two peaks were possibly attributed to the reduction of the surface and bulk Cu, respectively [47]. These results demonstrated the growth of Cu particles at high Cu loadings, which agreed with the above conclusion achieved in the XRD analysis. In addition, the result also indicated that a temperature at 300 °C was enough for the reduction of the Cu oxide to Cu metal. According to the XPS, XRD, and TPR analysis results, it is reasonable that the Cu component in the 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 after a reduction at 300 °C should mainly exist as a metallic state. Table 4 summarizes the catalytic reaction results in the HDO of 1,2-DDO under an H2 pressure of 5 MPa together with SBET values of the catalysts. The reactions were performed at 230 °C for a short reaction time of 15 min. With the increment in Cu loading from 4 to 20 wt%, the SBET of the catalyst samples gradually decreased. The conversion of 1,2-DDO gradually decreased with increasing the loading of Cu. A large loading of Cu such as 20 wt% led to the formation of large Cu particles and the decrement in SBET, that gave negative effects on the catalyst activity. On the other hand, the Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalysts with Cu loadings of 8–12 wt% provided relatively high selectivities to 1-decanol, and the highest 1-decanol selectivity of 81.4% was achieved over Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 with a Cu loading of 12 wt%. Because the XRD, XPS and TPR analysis results demonstrated that Cu existed as a metallic state after the reduction at 300 °C, Cu metal could work as the active sites in the HDO of 1,2-DDO to form 1-decanol. 3.3 HDO of 1,2-DDO over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 under different reaction conditions Table 5 shows the effect of reaction temperature in the HDO of 1,2-DDO over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3. The reaction temperature significantly affected the conversion of 1,2-DDO for a reaction time of 4 h. The conversion of 1,2-DDO was only 7.7% at 200 °C and it drastically increased to 83.8% at 230 °C. A complete conversion of 1,2-DDO was achieved at 250 °C and the selectivity to 1-decanol was 80.0% and 79.4% at 230 and 250 °C, respectively. An elevated temperature such as 280 °C promoted the formation of decenes as well as some unidentified products, leading to the decrement in the selectivity to 1-decanol. Therefore, a temperature at 230–250 °C was effective for the selective conversion of 1,2-DDO to form 1-decanol. Table 6 lists the catalytic reaction results in the HDO of 1,2-DDO over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 at 250 °C for different reaction times. The conversion of 1,2-DDO was 53.9% for a short reaction time of even 1 min. Because ca. 50 min was required during the heating from the room temperature to 250 °C, the started time should have counted during the heating process at temperatures higher than 200 °C. For comparison, the reaction at 230 °C was also performed for a reaction time of 1 min, and the conversion of 1,2-DDO was 29.5%. This result indicated that the reaction started during the heating process, and the heating during 230–250 °C was more efficient for the conversion of 1,2-DDO. Because it took ca. 16 min to reach the reaction temperature of 250 from 200 °C, the accurate reaction time could be plus 16 min to count the actual reaction time. The conversion of 1,2-DDO at 250 °C increased with increasing the reaction time, and the conversion of 1,2-DDO reached 100% within only 15 min. In contrast, the conversion of 1,2-DDO at 230 °C was 83.8% for a reaction time of even 4 h. Therefore, the reaction temperature was a key factor for the HDO of 1,2-DDO to form 1-decanol using Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst. The increment in the reaction temperature from 230 to 250 °C could significantly enhance the catalytic activity. The selectivity to 1-decanaol monotonically increased with increasing the reaction time up to 1 h. A reaction time longer than 1 h promoted the formation of decenes and decane, which should be produced through the further conversion of 1-decanol. Therefore, a long reaction time decreased the selectivity to 1-decanol. The optimal reaction time at 250 °C was adjudged to 1 h, giving a maximum 1-decanol selectivity of 82.3% at a 1,2-DDO conversion of 100%. The effects of H2 pressure were studied at 250 °C and a reaction time of 15 min. Table 7 summarizes the reaction results in the HDO of 1,2-DDO over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 at different H2 pressures. At a low H2 pressure of 0.1 MPa, the conversion of 1,2-DDO and the selectivity to 1-decanol were 95.0% and 5.5%, respectively, and they increased with increasing the H2 pressure. When the H2 pressure was 5 MPa or higher, the conversion reached 100%. A high H2 pressure promoted the formation of either 1-decanol or decane, which decreased the selectivity to decanal and 2-decanone. The hydrogenation of decenes at high H2 pressures should lead to the increment in the selectivity to decane. On the other hand, a high H2 pressure should promote the hydrogenation of decanal to form 1-decanol, which led to the decrement in the decanal selectivity under high H2 pressure conditions. The impact of H2 pressure became small at the H2 pressure higher than 7 MPa, and the highest 1-decanol selectivity was 84.7% at 10 MPa. Table 8 compares the reaction results in the present study with those in previous reports related to the HDO of 1,2-diols. Noble metal catalysts such as Rh, Pt, and Ir are generally used for the HDO reaction of 1,2-diols in previous reports: the reaction temperatures are mostly 100–120 °C and the selectivities to 1-alcohols are at a range of 70–90% [28–30,32,36,48]. In some cases, a high H2 pressure such as 8 MPa is required [28,29,35,36]. In the HDO of 1,2-propanediol over either Rh/SiO2 or Rh-ReOx/SiO2, the reaction temperature higher than 120 °C significantly decreases the selectivity to 1-propanol [28]. On the other hand, a long reaction time such as 24 or 48 h is required in some reactions [28,29,32,35,36]. As shown in Table 8, the productivities in the noble metal-catalyzed HDO reactions are much different. Rh-ReOx/SiO2 shows a relatively high 1-propanol productivity of 9.4 mmol gcat −1 h−1 in the HDO of 1,2-propanediol [28], and Ir-ReOx/SiO2 shows the highest 1-hexanol productivity of 4.8 mmol gcat −1 h−1 in the HDO of 1,2-hexanediol [48]. Non-noble metals such as Cu and Ni have also been applied in the HDO of 1,2-propandiol to produce 1-propanol: 1-propanol yields of ca. 90% can be achieved [49–51]. In contrast to noble metal catalysts, the non-noble metal catalysts require high reaction temperatures with a range of 180–260 °C. A high 1-proapnol productivity of 37 mmol gcat −1 h−1 can be achieved over a modified carbon-supported Ni catalyst at 260 °C [51]. In contrast to the reported noble metal catalysts, 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 requires a high reaction temperature of 250 °C, while the 1-decanol selectivity of ca. 80% can be obtained even at a high temperature of 250 °C. On the other hand, the 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3-catalyzed HDO reaction requires an extremely short reaction time for the complete conversion of 1,2-diols, which leads to a high productivity of 1-alcohol. The productivity of 1-decanol was 71 mmol gcat −1 h−1 in the HDO of 1,2-DDO over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 for a short reaction time of 15 min. To give a fair comparison with the noble metal-catalyzed reactions, the HDO of 1,2-hexanediol was also performed over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 under 5 MPa H2 at 250 °C for 15 min: 1,2-hexanediol conversion achieved 100% with the 1-hexanol selectivity of 70.2%, while the by-products were hexanal, hexenes, and hexane with the selectivity of 1.2%, 0.9%, and 0.1%, respectively. The productivity of 1-hexanol was 95 mmol gcat −1 h−1, which is ca. 20 times higher than that of 4.8 mmol gcat −1 h−1 in the HDO of 1,2-hexanediol over Ir-ReOx/SiO2 [48], demonstrating the extremely high productivity of 1-alcohol in the 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3-catalyzed HDO reactions again. 3.4 Study on the reaction mechanism The reaction mechanism in the HDO of 1,2-diols over Rh-ReOx/SiO2 and Ir-ReOx/SiO2 has been studied by Tomishige et al. [9,28]. The H2 species attacks the OH groups of 1,2-diols, and a secondary carbocation species is proposed as the reaction intermediate in the formation of 1-alcohol, while a primary carbocation species is proposed as the reaction intermediate in the formation of 2-alcohol. The formation of 1-alcohol is more favorable than 2-alcohol because a secondary carbocation species is more stable than a primary carbocation species. Meanwhile, Tomishige et al. have also studied the reaction mechanism in the direct synthesis of dioctyl ether via catalytic reduction of 1,2-octanediol over Pd-WOx/TiO2 catalyst at 180 °C [35]: 1,2-octanediol is primarily dehydrated to form octanal, which is further reacted with another diol to form an acetal, 2-heptyl-4-hexyl-1,3-dioxolane, which is converted to provide dioctyl ether via hydrogenolysis. In the HDO of 1,2-diols to form 1-alcohols over Rh-ReOx/C [30], Chia et al. suppose that RCH2-CH=O(+)H oxocarbenium ion is the intermediate, which is formed through the concerted elimination of water and hydride transfer from the primary -CH2OH group. The Rh-ReOx/C catalyst facilitates the initial acid-catalyzed carbenium ion chemistry followed by the metal-catalyzed hydrogenation. On the other hand, in the homogeneous HDO of 1,2-propanediol to 1-propanol over either a ruthenium complex [33] or an iridium pincer complex [37], propanal is proposed as the reaction intermediate, which is formed through the dehydration of 1,2-propanediol and is further hydrogenated to form 1-propanol. In the vapor-phase dehydration of 1,2-propanediol to propanal over acidic solids such as SiO2-Al2O3, heteropoly acids, and WO3/SiO2 at 200–300 °C [40,52,53], the produced propanal is reacted with another 1,2-propanediol to form an acetal of 2-ethyl-4-methyl-1,3-dioxolane at low conversions, while the dioxolane is decomposed to provide propanal at high conversions. In the presence of Cu and H2 in a vapor phase at 250 °C, however, propanal is readily decomposed into propylene via 1-propanol [54]. In the vapor phase, the formation of acetal in the reaction of several 1,2-diols is affected by the reaction temperature and the carbon-chain length of 1,2-diol [55]: low temperatures are favorable in the acetal formation and a long chain acetal is less formed than a short chain acetal. In the present study, we examined several reactions of different reactants by using different catalysts to discuss the reaction mechanism in the HDO of 1,2-DDO over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst. Decanal is a major by-product in the HDO of 1,2-DDO over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 (Table 7): a high H2 pressure decreases the selectivity to decanal, and thus increases the selectivity to 1-decanol. We have previously reported that a high H2 partial pressure is beneficial for the hydrogenation of an intermediate of propanal to form 1-propanol in the vapor-phase hydrogenolysis of glycerol [54]. Therefore, decanal is a possible intermediate in the HDO of 1,2-DDO to 1-decanol. In order to investigate the formation route of 1-decanol, the hydrogenation of decanal was performed over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 at 250 °C under 5 MPa H2 pressure with a short reaction of 15 min (the first row of Table 9): the selectivity to 1-decanol was 89.1% with a complete conversion of decanal. The hydrogenation also gave a complete conversion of decanal with an even higher 1-decanol selectivity of 92.2% at a low temperature of 200 °C (Table 9). Either the conversion or the selectivity to 1-decanol is similar to that in the HDO of 1,2-DDO over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3, indicating that 1-decanol is possibly formed through the hydrogenation of decanal. Solid acid catalysts, such as SiO2-Al2O3, γ-Al2O3, and zeolites, are generally effective for the vapor-phase dehydration of 1,2-propanediol to propanal [40]. Therefore, the dehydration of 1,2-DDO over acid catalysts should form decanal even in a liquid phase. The reaction over SiO2-Al2O3 without Cu loading was performed at 250 °C in N2 atmosphere for a reaction time of 15 min (the fifth row of Table 9). The conversion was 91.1%, while the selectivities to decanal and 1-decanol were 52.0% and 18.2%, respectively. The small amount of 1-decanol was possibly formed through the hydrogenation of decanal with a hydrogen-transfer pathway, in which 1,2-DDO was the H-donor. Nevertheless, this result has demonstrated that SiO2-Al2O3 can efficiently convert 1,2-DDO to form decanal at 250 °C. On the other hand, when the reactions over SiO2-Al2O3 in N2 atmosphere at 230 and 200 °C were performed, no 1-decanol was formed (the sixth and seventh rows of Table 9). On the other hand, the conversion of 1,2-DDO and the selectivity to decanal significantly increased with increasing the reaction temperature from 200 to 250 °C, indicating that the dehydration of 1,2-DDO to form decanal was highly dependent on the reaction temperature in this temperature range, and that decanal was also efficiently produced at a temperature range of 230–250 °C. The reaction over γ-Al2O3 was performed at 250 °C in N2 atmosphere for a reaction time of 15 min (the eighth row of Table 9). γ-Al2O3 gave a low conversion of 27.7%, and the selectivity to 1-decanol and decanal was 38.1% and 3.3%, respectively, indicating that γ-Al2O3 could not efficiently convert 1,2-DDO to form decanal. As a result, 12Cu/γ-Al2O3 was less active for the formation of 1-decanol compared with 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 (Table 3), indicating the importance of acid support in the reaction. In order to further verify the role of acidic SiO2-Al2O3 in the HDO of 1,2-DDO to 1-decanol, a neutral SiO2-supported Cu catalyst was prepared and tested. In the HDO of 1,2-DDO over 12Cu/SiO2 performed at 250 °C under 5 MPa H2 pressure for 4 h, the conversion of 1,2-DDO was only 9.3% and no 1-decanol was produced in the absence of acid component (the nineth row of Table 9). Because a conversion of 2.6% could be achieved even in the absence of a catalyst (the tenth row of Table 9), the catalytic activity of 12Cu/SiO2 without acid component was extremely low for the conversion of 1,2-DDO. The above results strongly support that decanal is the intermediate in the HDO of 1,2-DDO to form 1-decanol. Since the hydrogenation of decanal to form 1-decanol efficiently proceeds even at a low temperature of 200 °C, it is reasonable that the first step of 1,2-DDO dehydration to form decanal would be the rate-determining step in the HDO reaction of 1,2-DDO. Besides decanal, 2-decanone is also a by-product of dehydration of 1,2-DDO in most cases (Tables 3–7). 2-Decanone was actually produced from 1,2-DDO even in N2 over SiO2-Al2O3 at 250 °C (the fifth row of Table 9). Because the increment in either the reaction time or the H2 pressure decreased the formation of 2-decanone (Tables 6 and 7), the further hydrogenation of 2-decanone to form 2-decanol possibly proceeded under H2-pressured conditions, but 2-decanol was not actually detected in most cases. In order to understand the contribution of 1-decanol and 2-decanol in the formation of decenes and decane, the HDO of 1-decanol and 2-decanol over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 were performed at 250 °C under 5 MPa H2 pressure for 4 h (the third and fourth rows of Table 9). 1-Decanol was partially converted to decenes and decane, while the conversion was only 31.6%, whereas 2-decanol was mostly converted to decenes and decane with a conversion of 95.6%. Therefore, the high reactivity of 2-decanol led to the further conversion of 2-decanol to decenes and decane, although the hydrogenation of 2-decanone could form 2-decanol. In contrast, 1-decanol less contributed to the formation of decenes and decane especially at a short reaction time. Scheme 1 depicts the possible reaction pathway in the HDO of 1,2-DDO over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3. 1,2-DDO is primarily converted to form decanal over acidic SiO2-Al2O3, while 2-decanone with a small amount is also by-produced. Cu metals readily catalyze the hydrogenation of decanal to 1-decanol as well as the hydrogenation of 2-decanone to 2-decanol. Further dehydration of 2-decanol over acid sites forms decenes, which can be further hydrogenated to from decane over Cu metals. Besides, 1-decanol is less reactive and has a less contribution on the formation of decenes and decane. Therefore, the less reactive 1-decanol could be preferentially remained in the reaction media. 3.5 Stability of 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst We examined the reactions repeated using 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst for several times in order to verify the catalyst stability. The used catalyst was reduced at 300 °C for 1 h before the next run. Table 10 summarizes the reaction results. The conversion of 1,2-DDO was 99.9% and the selectivity to 1-decanol was 75.5% in the 1st recycle run. In contrast to the catalytic activity of the fresh 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3, a slight decrement in the selectivity to 1-decanol was observed in the 1st recycle run. However, 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 showed an excellent stability during the 2–5 recycle runs with the conversion of 1,2-DDO kept at 99.9% and the selectivity to 1-decanol kept at ca. 78%. Therefore, no significant deactivation was observed in the 5 recycle runs. Fig. 6 displays the TEM images of the fresh 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 sample and that used after the fifth recycle run. CuO particles in fresh 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 were well dispersed on the surface of the support with an average particle size of ca. 7.8 nm (Fig. 6a). On the other hand, the average Cu particle size increased to 10.4 nm after 5 recycle runs (Fig. 6b). The growth of Cu particle size should be caused by the agglutination of Cu particles during the reaction. Nevertheless, the growth of Cu particle size did not significantly decrease the catalytic activity. 4 Conclusions The catalytic activity of various non-noble metal-based solid catalysts was investigated in the HDO of 1,2-DDO to 1-decanol. Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst with a mesopore structure, a moderate SBET, and a relatively weak acidity exhibited a high catalytic performance for the formation of 1-decanol. A complete conversion of 1,2-DDO with a 1-decanol selectivity of 76.9% was achieved over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 at 250 °C and 5 MPa of H2 within only 15 min, and the selectivity to 1-decanol could reach 82.3% for 1 h. The conversion of 1,2-DDO at 5 MPa for 4 h increased dramatically from 7.7% to 100% with increasing the reaction temperature from 200 to 250 °C because the first step of dehydration of 1,2-DDO to decanal was significantly affected by the reaction temperature. In contrast to the noble metal-based catalysts previously reported, a high reaction temperature such as 250 °C was required for the 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst. On the other hand, 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst was more efficient for the formation of 1-alcohol than noble metal catalysts on the total yield of 1-alcohol. The productivity of 1-decanol was 71 mmol gcat −1 h−1 in the HDO of 1,2-DDO over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 at 250 °C and an H2 pressure of 5 MPa, which could be further increased to 78 mmol gcat −1 h−1 at an H2 pressure of 10 MPa. The study on the reaction mechanism revealed that decanal was the reaction intermediate in the HDO of 1,2-DDO over 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3. In addition, 12Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 exhibited an excellent stability, and no significant deactivation of catalyst was observed in five repeated runs. coredata.dc:description: Liquid-phase catalytic hydrodeoxygenation of 1,2-decanediol (1,2-DDO) to form 1-decanol was performed over various non-noble metal-loaded acidic catalysts, and Cu loaded on amorphous SiO2-Al2O3 exhibited a high catalytic activity for the formation of 1-decanol. A high 1-decanol selectivity of 84.7% with a complete 1,2-DDO conversion was obtained within only 15 min over the Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 at 250 °C under 10 MPa H2 pressure. The temperature at 250 °C and the H2 pressure higher than 3 MPa were conducive to the efficient production of 1-decanol from 1,2-DDO. In contrast to the previously reported noble metal catalysts, Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 required a relatively high reaction temperature, while an extremely high 1-decanol productivity of 78 mmol gcat −1 h−1 could be achieved. Meanwhile, the hydrodeoxygenation of 1,2-decanediol over Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 proceeded via a reaction mechanism in which decanal was formed as the intermediate. In addition, the Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst was reusable at least five times without serious deactivation.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrodeoxygenation of 1,2-decanediol to produce 1-decanol over Cu/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst
